Author Affiliations: Microelectronics and Implantable Systems, University of Innsbruck, Innsbruck, Austria; Microelectronics and Implantable Systems, University of Innsbruck, Innsbruck, Austria; Microelectronics and Implantable Systems, University of Innsbruck, Innsbruck, Austria; Microelectronics and Implantable Systems, University of Innsbruck, Innsbruck, Austria; Microelectronics and Implantable Systems, University of Innsbruck, Innsbruck, Austria
Publication Title: 2023 International Conference on Electromagnetics in Advanced Applications (ICEAA)
Abstract: This paper proposes a solution for wireless monitoring of concrete structures using batteryless wireless sensor nodes based on UHF RFID technology. The system comprises a reader device and one or more wireless sensor nodes, which are connected to various sensors. The wireless sensor nodes are powered by the reader, and the communication protocol is based on ISO 18000-63. An external chloride sensor is used to gauge the concentration of chloride ions, which indicate the degree of corrosion of the concrete structure. The proposed system eliminates the need for cables or batteries and allows for data collection in hard-to-reach areas. To ensure reliable operation of the system, an automated antenna design methodology has been proposed that utilizes a pixelated structure based on a cross-shaped pattern. The methodology employs an evolutionary algorithm to generate an initial population of antenna designs, which are subjected to electromagnetic simulation using a commercial simulation tool. The performance of the sensor platform was evaluated in concrete blocks, and the results demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed approach for monitoring concrete structures.

Document Title: Semi-Supervised Latent Diffusion Model: Reverse Design of Dual-Polarization Frequency-Selective Metasurface
Authors: H. Shan; T. Jiang
Author Affiliations: Department of Information and Communication Engineering, Harbin Engineering University, Harbin, China; Department of Information and Communication Engineering, Harbin Engineering University, Harbin, China
Publication Title: IEEE Transactions on Antennas and Propagation
Abstract: To avoid the complex design process for the pixelate frequency-selective metasurface, a semi-supervised latent diffusion model (S-LDM) is proposed in this article. S-LDM uses polarization-independent TE and TM spectrums to guide the denoising of random Gaussian noise, and a semi-supervised learning strategy is adopted for training the latent diffusion model (LDM). First, the modified National Institute of Standards and Technology (MNIST) dataset and its extended version are selected for constructing the polarization-independence frequency-selective metasurface with asymmetry  $28\times 28$  pixelates. Then, an autoencoder (AE) network is adopted to compress the  $28\times 28$  metasurface pattern (MSP) into an  $8\times 8$  latent space, and such compression method has effectively shortened the training time. Next, pseudolabels for unlabeled data are constructed, and their loss values are added as dynamic regularization weights in the total loss function. In doing so, S-LDM generates more precise metasurfaces than supervised training. Full-wave simulation results demonstrate that the dual-polarization frequency-selective metasurfaces can be accurately reverse-generated based on the desired TE–TM spectrum in the test dataset. Reverse design metasurfaces have also been successfully achieved by randomly generating Gaussian spectrums with various frequency-selective and polarization capabilities. Finally, a real-world metasurface is fabricated by S-LDM. The measurement results of this metasurface show the obvious dual-polarization frequency-selective characteristic.

Abstract: This article presents a deep-learning-based approach for designing Class F power amplifiers (PAs). We use convolutional neural networks (CNNs) to predict the scattering parameters of pixelated electromagnetic (EM) layouts. Using a CNN-based surrogate model and an evolutionary algorithm, we synthesize complex Class F output networks. As a proof of concept, we implement a gallium nitride (GaN) HEMT Class F PA, achieving a measured output power of 41.6 dBm and a drain efficiency of 74% at 2.9 GHz. The prototype also linearly reproduces a 20-MHz modulated signal with an 8.5-dB peak-to-average power ratio (PAPR), achieving an adjacent channel leakage ratio (ACLR) of −50.7 dBc with digital predistortion (DPD). To the best of our knowledge, this is the first deep-learning-based Class F PA design using pixelated layout structures.

Document Title: Calibration of Active Electronically Scanned Arrays on Aerial Vehicles Through SAR Image Formation
Authors: D. Madden; K. Sarabandi
Author Affiliations: The Universtiy of Michigan, Ann Arbor, MI, USA; The Universtiy of Michigan, Ann Arbor, MI, USA
Publication Title: 2023 IEEE International Symposium on Antennas and Propagation and USNC-URSI Radio Science Meeting (USNC-URSI)
Abstract: In-situ calibration of Active Electronically Scanned Arrays (AESA) is a challenging problem that is still considered open. In this paper we propose a novel method for calibration of such arrays on aerial vehicles using the backscatter from the terrain below. To limit the extent of the terrestrial targets, the relative motion of the vehicle with respect to the ground can be used to form a pixelated synthetic aperture radar (SAR) image of the scene. The individual pixels of this image are used as calibration targets for a pair of transmitter and receiver modules. This way for an array with N transceiver modules, $\boldsymbol{NXN}$ SAR images can be formed, co-registered, and used to determine the phase variations across the array elements. It is interesting to note that the measured phase difference between the backscatter from two co-registered SAR images can be averaged over all pixels to provide a much better estimate of the array phase error. Array channels can be aligned within the measurement phase errors, allowing for calibration without the needs for signals-of-opportunity or strategically placed calibration targets. Monte Carlo simulation of array beamforming with random phase difference errors on each element can then be used to determine degradation of array performance metrics.

Abstract: In this paper, an intelligent design optimization method based on Long Short Term Memory (LSTM) neural networks is introduced, aiming at designing discrete pixelated meta-atom structure with high efficient microwave absorption across a wide band. By rapid generation and selection of metaatom pairs with both high absorption and stable broadband phase differences, an absorption scattering integrated coding metasurface realized with optically transparent ITO film can be obtained by random arranging the two kinds of meta-atoms. Authors: F. -F. Wang; Q. H. Liu
Author Affiliations: School of Electronic Science and Engineering, Nanjing University of Posts and Telecommunications, Nanjing, China; Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering, Duke University, Durham, USA
Publication Title: IEEE Transactions on Antennas and Propagation
Abstract: High-frequency electromagnetic inverse scattering of conductors has many practical applications. Its goal is to reconstruct the shape of conductors from their scattered fields at some distances. When viewed from the pixelated imaging viewpoint, any pixel in the imaging domain is either a conductor or background (air); thus such an inverse scattering problem has binary solutions for all pixels. Under the high-frequency physical optics (PO) approximation, the scattered field is formulated as a linear problem in terms of a local binary shape function. A binary inversion method is proposed for the detection and shape reconstruction of a flat PEC reflector from high-frequency scattered field measurements. To exploit the underlying binary structure, a Bernoulli-Gaussian (BG) prior model is employed to perform a binary enforcement mechanism. This binary enforcement mechanism can push each pixel of the inversion domain to have a value equal to either zero or one. Then, the damped generalized approximate message passing (GAMP) is integrated with the proposed prior model to address the binary linear inverse problem from the Bayesian inference perspective. Numerical examples are presented to demonstrate the effectiveness and robustness of the proposed BG Binary Inversion method. The performance improvement of the proposed method is attributed to the exploitation of the binary prior information of the solution and GAMP technique.

Abstract: This work presents a pixelated liquid-crystal-driven terahertz (THz) reconfigurable intelligent surface (RIS) with a vertical cross structure. Abstract: To enhance design flexibility for frequency selective surfaces (FSSs), a machine learning-based inverse topological design method (ITDM) incorporating non-uniform rational B-splines (NURBSs), termed NURBS-ITDM, is proposed in this work. The proposed method utilizes NURBS curves to model the metallic pattern geometry on the substrate of the FSS unit cell. This method significantly expands the flexibility in defining patch or aperture shapes while reducing the number of modeling variables, thereby mitigating computational complexity and training burden. Furthermore, the inherent smoothness and continuity of NURBS curves eliminate jagged boundaries and point connection artifacts common in pixelated representations. The effectiveness of the proposed NURBS-ITDM is validated through two numerical examples, including a single-layer FSS with a rectangular unit cell and a double-layer FSS with a regular hexagonal unit cell. The designed double-layer FSS structures is fabricated and measured to further verify the performance of the proposed model.
